title: Isaiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 10.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:1, who is warned with 'Woe'?
options: Them that decree unrighteous decrees
The poor of my people
The Assyrian king
The remnant of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Them that decree unrighteous decrees
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:1 begins with 'Woe unto them that decree unrighteous decrees,' warning those who make unjust laws.

questions.question: What are widows and the fatherless described as in Isaiah 10:2?
options: Their prey
Protected by the law
Leaders of the people
Builders of the city
questions.correctAnswer: Their prey
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:2 states that widows may be their prey and that they may rob the fatherless when justice is denied.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10:5, who is called 'the rod of mine anger'?
options: The Assyrian
The king of Israel
The prophet Isaiah
The remnant of Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: The Assyrian
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:5 identifies the Assyrian as 'the rod of mine anger,' used by God to execute judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 10:7 says the Assyrian king intends to destroy many nations.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:7 clearly states that the Assyrian's heart is to destroy and cut off many nations.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:9, which city is compared to Damascus?
options: Samaria
Calno
Hamath
Arpad
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:9 asks, 'Is not Samaria as Damascus?' comparing these two cities.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 10:13: 'By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my ______; for I am prudent.'
options: wisdom
power
might
courage
questions.correctAnswer: wisdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:13 says the Assyrian boasts 'by the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my wisdom; for I am prudent.'

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10:15 compare the axe and saw to?
options: Boasting against the one who uses them
Tools for building
Symbols of peace
Weapons of war
questions.correctAnswer: Boasting against the one who uses them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:15 asks if the axe should boast against him that heweth with it, showing tools should not boast against their users.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 10:20 says the remnant of Israel will continue to rely on the one who smote them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:20 states that the remnant of Israel 'shall no more again stay upon him that smote them; but shall stay upon the LORD.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:21, to whom will the remnant of Jacob return?
options: The mighty God
The king of Assyria
The princes of the earth
The idols
questions.correctAnswer: The mighty God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:21 says the remnant of Jacob will return unto the mighty God.

questions.question: What is the Lord's message to the people dwelling in Zion in Isaiah 10:24?
options: Be not afraid of the Assyrian
Prepare for war
Flee to Egypt
Offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Be not afraid of the Assyrian
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:24 instructs the people in Zion not to fear the Assyrian who will smite them.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:27, what will happen to the yoke from off the neck?
options: It shall be destroyed because of the anointing
It will become heavier
It will be passed to another
It will remain forever
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be destroyed because of the anointing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:27 promises that the yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 10:33 says that the high ones of stature shall be exalted.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:33 says the high ones of stature shall be hewn down and the haughty humbled.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10:17, the light of Israel is described as what?
options: A fire
A cloud
A river
A mountain
questions.correctAnswer: A fire
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:17 describes the light of Israel as a fire and His Holy One as a flame.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:22, though Israel's people are like the sand of the sea, what will happen?
options: A remnant of them shall return
All shall be destroyed
They shall be scattered forever
They shall become kings
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant of them shall return
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:22 assures that though Israel is numerous, a remnant will return.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 10:4: 'Without me they shall bow down under the prisoners, and they shall fall under the ______.'
options: slain
enemy
king
judgment
questions.correctAnswer: slain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:4 says they shall fall under the slain without God's help.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during difficult times when injustice seems to prevail. Based on Isaiah 10, what biblical truth would you share about God’s control over nations and their rulers?
options: God uses even powerful nations like Assyria to accomplish His purposes
God abandons His people when evil rulers rise
Human rulers always act independently of God's will
God’s anger is limited and soon ends without effect
questions.correctAnswer: God uses even powerful nations like Assyria to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:5-6 shows that God calls Assyria 'the rod of mine anger' and uses it to execute judgment. Verses 12 and 24 emphasize God's sovereign control over the Assyrian king and His plans to punish him after His work is done.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 teach us about humility when dealing with pride and self-reliance?
options: Pride leads to downfall because God humbles the haughty
Pride is a sign of God's blessing
Self-reliance is encouraged to overcome challenges
Humble people are often forgotten by God
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall because God humbles the haughty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:33 states that the 'high ones of stature shall be hewn down, and the haughty shall be humbled,' teaching that pride results in judgment. This encourages humility before God.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to seek help from worldly powers rather than God. According to Isaiah 10, what is the proper place to trust in times of trouble?
options: Trust in the LORD, the Holy One of Israel
Trust in earthly kings and armies
Trust in wealth and possessions
Trust in one's own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD, the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:20-21 encourages the remnant of Israel to no longer rely on their oppressors but to trust in the LORD in truth, highlighting faithful dependence on God over worldly powers.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10 teach about God’s discipline and its purpose in the life of His people?
options: God’s discipline is temporary and leads to eventual restoration
God’s discipline is permanent and without hope
God never disciplines His people
Discipline is a sign of God’s rejection
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline is temporary and leads to eventual restoration
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:25 and 27 speak of indignation ceasing and the removal of the yoke due to God's anointing, signifying that discipline is corrective and will end in deliverance and restoration.

questions.question: A believer wants to know how to respond to trials that feel overwhelming. What does Isaiah 10 say about God’s ongoing anger and eventual mercy?
options: God’s anger is stretched out but will ultimately cease with mercy
God’s anger is endless and without relief
God ignores the suffering of His people
Mercy is given without any discipline
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger is stretched out but will ultimately cease with mercy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:4 describes God’s anger as stretched out still, but verse 25 assures that indignation will cease soon, teaching that God’s discipline is measured and followed by mercy.

questions.question: How does this chapter instruct believers concerning integrity and honesty in leadership and judgment?
options: Leaders must not decree unrighteous decrees or deny justice to the needy
Leaders should favor the rich and powerful
Justice is optional in difficult times
Partiality is acceptable for political gain
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must not decree unrighteous decrees or deny justice to the needy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:1-2 warns against making unjust laws and turning aside the needy from judgment, emphasizing the importance of integrity and fairness in leadership.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 10, God uses even a nation like Assyria, which does not realize His purpose, to carry out His judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:7 explains that Assyria does not intend to fulfill God's purpose, but God uses them to destroy nations as part of His plan, demonstrating His sovereignty over human intentions.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 10 teaches that the remnant of Israel will be completely destroyed and no one will return to God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:22-23 promises that though Israel is numerous like the sand of the sea, a remnant will return to God, showing hope and restoration after judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Shall the axe boast itself against him that heweth therewith? or shall the saw magnify itself against him that ____ it?"
options: shaketh
cuts
lifts
holds
questions.correctAnswer: shaketh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:15 uses this metaphor to demonstrate that tools cannot boast against their users, illustrating the futility of pride against God's sovereignty.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 illustrate the importance of faith and trust in God during oppression?
options: The remnant will rely on the LORD and not on their oppressors
Faith is irrelevant during oppression
Trust should be placed in military strength alone
Oppression is permanent and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant will rely on the LORD and not on their oppressors
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:20-21 teaches that the remnant of Israel will no longer depend on those who smote them but will trust in the Holy One of Israel, emphasizing faith in God over fear of enemies.

questions.question: A Christian facing temptation to exploit others for personal gain asks for guidance. What does Isaiah 10 warn about such behavior?
options: Exploiting the needy and widows leads to God’s judgment
It is acceptable if it benefits you
God rewards those who gain by any means
Exploitation is unnoticed by God
questions.correctAnswer: Exploiting the needy and widows leads to God’s judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:1-2 condemns decreeing unrighteous laws and turning away justice from the needy, highlighting God’s displeasure with exploitation and injustice.

questions.question: What practical lesson about contentment and gratitude does Isaiah 10 teach through the imagery of gathering spoils?
options: All riches are ultimately under God’s control and cannot boast against Him
We should boast in our riches and treasures
Accumulating wealth by any means is praiseworthy
Riches guarantee God’s favor
questions.correctAnswer: All riches are ultimately under God’s control and cannot boast against Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:13-15 describes how God’s hand gathers all the earth’s riches and questions whether tools can boast against their user, teaching humility and recognition of God’s sovereignty over wealth.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 encourage believers to respond to the fear of enemies and trials?
options: Do not be afraid of the Assyrian; God’s indignation will cease
Fear is the proper response to all enemies
Rely only on human strength to overcome
Enemies will never be defeated
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be afraid of the Assyrian; God’s indignation will cease
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:24-25 encourages God’s people not to fear the Assyrian because God’s anger will end soon, teaching trust and patience in God’s deliverance.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: Though trials come, God’s anger is limited and will end, leading to restoration
Trials are endless and without purpose
God leaves His people without hope during suffering
Perseverance is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: Though trials come, God’s anger is limited and will end, leading to restoration
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:25 and 27 show that God’s indignation will cease soon and that burdens will be removed because of His anointing, teaching perseverance and hope in God’s timing.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 teach about God’s justice in relation to the proud and arrogant?
options: God will lop the bough with terror and humble the haughty
God ignores the proud
Pride always leads to blessing
Arrogance is rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: God will lop the bough with terror and humble the haughty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:33 describes God’s judgment on the proud, cutting them down and humbling them, reminding believers to cultivate humility.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 10.

questions.question: What role does the Assyrian play according to Isaiah 10:5 in the context of divine judgment?
options: He is a tool of God's anger and indignation
He is a rebellious king defying God
He is a deliverer of Israel
He is a neutral observer
questions.correctAnswer: He is a tool of God's anger and indignation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:5 states that the Assyrian is the "rod of mine anger, and the staff in their hand is mine indignation," indicating he is used by God as an instrument of judgment.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10:7, what is the Assyrian king's true intent, despite his claims?
options: To destroy and cut off many nations
To establish peace with Israel
To honor God with his conquests
To protect the poor and needy
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy and cut off many nations
questions.explanation: The verse reveals that although the Assyrian does not acknowledge it, his heart is set to "destroy and cut off nations not a few," showing his destructive ambition.

questions.question: Isaiah 10:15 uses the imagery of an axe and a saw. What theological principle is illustrated by this metaphor?
options: No created instrument can boast against its creator
Wood is superior to metal in strength
The Assyrian is more powerful than God
Human wisdom surpasses divine wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: No created instrument can boast against its creator
questions.explanation: The metaphor indicates that tools like the axe or saw cannot magnify themselves over the one who wields them, illustrating God’s sovereignty over the Assyrian (Isaiah 10:15).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:20, upon whom will the remnant of Israel rely after the Assyrian oppression?
options: The LORD, the Holy One of Israel
The king of Assyria
Foreign allies
Their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD, the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:20 states the remnant will no longer rely on their oppressors but will trust in the LORD in truth.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'his yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing' in Isaiah 10:27?
options: It symbolizes liberation through divine empowerment
It indicates continued oppression
It refers to a political alliance
It means the yoke will be passed to another nation
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes liberation through divine empowerment
questions.explanation: The 'anointing' refers to God's empowering presence that will break the burden and yoke of Assyrian oppression (Isaiah 10:27), symbolizing liberation.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10:12 describe God's judgment on the king of Assyria after His work is done on Zion and Jerusalem?
options: God will punish the king's pride and haughtiness
God will bless the king for his victories
God will ignore the king's actions
God will make the king a protector of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will punish the king's pride and haughtiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:12 promises punishment for the "fruit of the stout heart of the king of Assyria" and his "high looks," indicating judgment on his arrogance.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 10:22 portrays that despite Israel's multitude, only a remnant will return due to a righteous judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:22 states that though Israel's people are as numerous as the sand of the sea, only a remnant shall return, illustrating the theme of a preserved remnant through divine judgment.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10:3, what question is posed about the day of visitation and desolation?
options: To whom will you flee for help and where will you leave your glory?
Who will rise up and defend you?
What idols will protect you?
How many will survive the destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: To whom will you flee for help and where will you leave your glory?
questions.explanation: Verse 3 asks about the helplessness in the day of God's visitation, questioning where people will seek help and where their glory will go.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 10:13-14 to emphasize the Assyrian king's arrogance?
options: Metaphor comparing the king to a mighty hunter gathering eggs
Simile describing the king as a lion
Allegory of a lost sheep
Parable of the prodigal son
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor comparing the king to a mighty hunter gathering eggs
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:14 uses the metaphor of gathering eggs left in a nest to portray the king's confident plundering and arrogance.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:16, what will the LORD send among the 'fat ones'?
options: Leanness and a burning like fire
Peace and prosperity
Rain and harvest
Wisdom and understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Leanness and a burning like fire
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes the LORD sending leanness and kindling a fire under the proud ones, symbolizing judgment and purification.

questions.question: What historical event is alluded to in Isaiah 10:26 that symbolizes God's judgment against Assyria?
options: The slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb
The crossing of the Red Sea
The fall of Jericho
The Babylonian exile
questions.correctAnswer: The slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:26 references the Midianite defeat at Oreb, symbolizing a decisive divine judgment against Assyria.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 10:11 draws a parallel between the fate of Samaria and _____.
options: Jerusalem and her idols
Babylon and its towers
Egypt and its gods
Nineveh and its king
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem and her idols
questions.explanation: The verse states God will do to Jerusalem and her idols as He has done to Samaria and her idols, indicating parallel judgment.

questions.question: Which cities are compared in Isaiah 10:9 to emphasize the Assyrian king's claim of conquering great kingdoms?
options: Calno and Carchemish; Hamath and Arpad; Samaria and Damascus
Jerusalem and Babylon; Nineveh and Tyre
Egypt and Assyria; Moab and Edom
Sodom and Gomorrah; Zoar and Admah
questions.correctAnswer: Calno and Carchemish; Hamath and Arpad; Samaria and Damascus
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:9 lists these city pairs to highlight the Assyrian king’s boast of conquering prominent kingdoms.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10:24, how should the people of Zion respond to the Assyrian threat?
options: Not be afraid of the Assyrian
Form alliances with Egypt
Flee to the mountains
Prepare for battle immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Not be afraid of the Assyrian
questions.explanation: Verse 24 instructs the people not to fear the Assyrian, despite his rod and staff raised against them, as God's plan will prevail.

questions.question: What is the ultimate fate of the 'high ones of stature' and the 'haughty' according to Isaiah 10:33?
options: They shall be hewn down and humbled
They shall be exalted
They shall flee and escape
They shall be crowned kings
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be hewn down and humbled
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:33 states that the Lord will lop the bough with terror, cutting down the high and humbling the haughty as judgment.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10, what is the primary reason God sends the Assyrian against His people?
options: To punish a hypocritical nation and execute His wrath
To establish a new kingdom for the Assyrians
To bring peace and prosperity to Israel
To test the faith of the people
questions.correctAnswer: To punish a hypocritical nation and execute His wrath
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:5-6 states that God uses the Assyrian as the 'rod of mine anger' to punish a hypocritical nation. This aligns with God's justice seen in Romans 1:18 and Nahum 1:2 where God punishes sin. It also illustrates divine sovereignty over nations as in Daniel 4:17 and Isaiah 45:1.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10, what is described as the consequence for those who write unrighteous decrees and oppress the needy?
options: They will face God's visitation and desolation
They will become rulers over Israel
They will receive great wealth and honor
They will be forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: They will face God's visitation and desolation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:1-3 warns against unjust decrees and oppressing the poor, stating that on the day of visitation, there will be desolation. This reflects God's justice throughout Scripture (Proverbs 22:22-23, Ezekiel 22:29, James 5:4, Psalm 82:3-4).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10 say about the Assyrian king’s understanding of his own mission?
options: He does not realize God is using him to destroy nations
He knows he is God's instrument and willingly submits
He seeks to bring peace and restore Israel
He prays for mercy from God
questions.correctAnswer: He does not realize God is using him to destroy nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:7 explains the Assyrian king's heart is not aligned with God's purpose; he intends his own destruction of nations, unaware he is serving God's judgment. This reflects themes in Proverbs 21:1 and Habakkuk 1:5-11 about God directing rulers’ hearts.

questions.question: What is the significance of the rhetorical question about the axe and the wood in Isaiah 10:15?
options: It illustrates that human pride is absurd against God’s sovereignty
It teaches that tools are more powerful than their users
It shows the axe is stronger than the wood
It encourages rebellion against rulers
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates that human pride is absurd against God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:15 uses the metaphor of an axe and its user to show that human instruments of power cannot boast against God who wields them. This theme is consistent with Job 12:10, Proverbs 16:4, Psalm 115:3, and Romans 9:17 about God's absolute control.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 10, what will God do to the 'fat ones' or the proud under His glory?
options: Send leanness and kindle a burning fire upon them
Make them kings over other nations
Bless them with peace and prosperity
Hide them from judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Send leanness and kindle a burning fire upon them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:16-18 describes God's judgment on the proud as sending leanness and a consuming fire, symbolizing purification and destruction, similar to passages like Ezekiel 28:18, Malachi 3:2, Hebrews 12:29, and Revelation 20:9.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10 say about the remnant of Israel after the judgment?
options: They will rely no longer on the oppressor but on the Lord in truth
They will be completely destroyed without survivors
They will abandon the Lord for foreign gods
They will establish an earthly kingdom by their own power
questions.correctAnswer: They will rely no longer on the oppressor but on the Lord in truth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:20-21 teaches that the remnant of Israel will trust in the Holy One of Israel rather than their oppressors, consistent with God's faithfulness in preserving a faithful remnant (Romans 9:27, Zechariah 13:8-9, Jeremiah 23:3, 1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: In Isaiah 10, how does God describe the extent of the remnant that will return?
options: Like the sand of the sea, a small portion will return
All Israel will return without exception
Only a single family will survive
No one will return; all will perish
questions.correctAnswer: Like the sand of the sea, a small portion will return
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:22 states though Israel’s people are numerous, only a remnant will return, reflecting God's sovereign preservation of a faithful few, consistent with passages like Romans 11:5, Isaiah 1:9, Zephaniah 3:13, and Jeremiah 31:7.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'indignation' and 'anger' mentioned in Isaiah 10:25?
options: They are God’s righteous wrath that will cease after the oppressor's destruction
They are human emotions without divine purpose
They are signs of God’s rejection of His people forever
They indicate God’s pleasure with the Assyrian conquest
questions.correctAnswer: They are God’s righteous wrath that will cease after the oppressor's destruction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:25 shows God’s indignation as a temporary, purposeful judgment that will cease following the destruction of the oppressors. This aligns with God's just anger in Exodus 34:6-7, Nahum 1:3, Psalm 7:11, and Romans 2:5.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10:27 reveal about the removal of the Assyrian yoke from Israel?
options: It will be destroyed because of the anointing
It will be replaced by a harsher yoke
It will remain forever as a sign of punishment
It will be lifted only after Israel conquers Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: It will be destroyed because of the anointing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:27 promises the yoke will be broken due to the anointing, indicating God’s empowerment to deliver His people, consistent with themes in Luke 4:18-19, Psalm 2:6, Isaiah 61:1, and Acts 10:38 regarding the Messiah’s anointing to bring liberation.

questions.question: What does the imagery of cutting down the thickets of the forest with iron in Isaiah 10:34 symbolize?
options: God’s decisive and powerful judgment against pride and wickedness
A literal deforestation unrelated to judgment
The growth of Israel’s power over the forest
A peaceful restoration of nature
questions.correctAnswer: God’s decisive and powerful judgment against pride and wickedness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:34 uses iron cutting down forests as a metaphor for God’s unstoppable judgment. This imagery echoes the power of God's word (Hebrews 4:12), His judgment on nations (Jeremiah 51:20), and His destruction of evil (Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 describe the Assyrian’s attitude towards his own achievements in verses 13-14?
options: He boasts in his own strength and wisdom
He humbly credits God for his success
He doubts the significance of his conquests
He regrets his actions and seeks forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: He boasts in his own strength and wisdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:13-14 shows the king of Assyria arrogantly claiming credit for his conquests by his own strength and wisdom, illustrating human pride opposed to God’s sovereignty, similar to Proverbs 16:18, Jeremiah 49:16, Daniel 4:30, and James 4:6.

questions.question: In Isaiah 10, what question does God ask to demonstrate the folly of the Assyrian king’s pride (Isaiah 10:8-9)?
options: Are not my princes altogether kings? Is not Calno as Carchemish?
Why do you worship idols instead of Me?
Will the Assyrian not be humbled?
Can the Assyrian defeat the God of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Are not my princes altogether kings? Is not Calno as Carchemish?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:8-9 uses rhetorical questions about rulers and cities to challenge the Assyrian king’s pride, asserting God’s sovereign authority over all rulers, as supported by Psalm 47:7, Daniel 2:21, Romans 13:1, and Colossians 1:16.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 10 teach about God’s control over the nations and their rulers?
options: God raises and uses nations to accomplish His purposes
Nations act independently without God’s knowledge
God supports only Israel’s enemies
Rulers have ultimate authority apart from God
questions.correctAnswer: God raises and uses nations to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:5-7 shows God using the Assyrian as an instrument of judgment, affirming divine sovereignty over nations. This is consistent with passages like Daniel 4:17, Proverbs 21:1, Romans 9:17, and Isaiah 45:1.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 10 depict the fate of those who oppress widows and fatherless children?
options: They will face God’s judgment and desolation
They will be rewarded with wealth
They will receive forgiveness without repentance
They will become leaders in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will face God’s judgment and desolation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:1-2 condemns those who oppress the needy, widows, and fatherless, promising judgment on them. This aligns with biblical themes in Psalm 68:5, Exodus 22:22-24, James 1:27, and Proverbs 31:8-9 about God defending the vulnerable.

questions.question: What is the ultimate reason given in Isaiah 10 for the destruction of the proud and haughty?
options: Because of their arrogance and opposition to God
Because they worship idols correctly
Because they are chosen by God for blessing
Because they seek peace among nations
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their arrogance and opposition to God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 10:12-13 and 33 show God punishing the king of Assyria for his proud heart and haughty looks. This reflects God's judgment on pride throughout Scripture (Proverbs 16:5, Luke 1:51, James 4:6, 1 Peter 5:5).
